100.description: This interim response indicates that the client should continue the request or ignore the response if the request is already finished.

101.description: This code is sent in response to an Upgrade request header from the client and indicates the protocol the server is switching to.

102.description: This code indicates that the server has received and is processing the request, but no response is available yet.

201.description: The request succeeded, and a new resource was created as a result.

202.description: The request has been received but not yet acted upon.

203.description: This response code means the returned metadata is not exactly the same as is available from the origin server, but is collected from a local or a third-party copy.

204.description: There is no content to send for this request, but the headers may be useful.

205.description: Tells the user agent to reset the document which sent this request.

206.description: This response code is used when the Range header is sent from the client to request only part of a resource.

207.description: Conveys information about multiple resources, for situations where multiple status codes might be appropriate.

208.description: Used inside a <dav:propstat> response element to avoid repeatedly enumerating the internal members of multiple bindings to the same collection.

226.description: The server has fulfilled a GET request for the resource, and the response is a representation of the result of one or more instance-manipulations applied to the current instance.

300.description: The request has more than one possible response.

301.description: The URL of the requested resource has been changed permanently.

302.description: This response code means that the URI of requested resource has been changed temporarily.

303.description: The server sent this response to direct the client to get the requested resource at another URI with a GET request.

304.description: This is used for caching purposes.

305.description: Defined in a previous version of the HTTP specification to indicate that a requested response must be accessed by a proxy.

306.description: This response code is no longer used; it is just reserved.

307.description: The server sends this response to direct the client to get the requested resource at another URI with the same method that was used in the prior request.

308.description: This means that the resource is now permanently located at another URI, specified by the Location: HTTP Response header.

400.description: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error.

401.description: The client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.

402.description: This response code is reserved for future use.

403.description: The client does not have access rights to the content.

404.description: The server cannot find the requested resource.

405.description: The request method is known by the server but is not supported by the target resource.

406.description: This response is sent when the web server, after performing server-driven content negotiation, doesn't find any content that conforms to the criteria given by the user agent.

407.description: This is similar to 401 Unauthorized but authentication is needed to be done by a proxy.

408.description: This response is sent on an idle connection by some servers, even without any previous request by the client.

409.description: This response is sent when a request conflicts with the current state of the server.

410.description: This response is sent when the requested content has been permanently deleted from server, with no forwarding address.

411.description: Server rejected the request because the Content-Length header field is not defined and the server requires it.

412.description: The client has indicated preconditions in its headers which the server does not meet.

413.description: Request entity is larger than limits defined by server.

414.description: The URI requested by the client is longer than the server is willing to interpret.

415.description: The media format of the requested data is not supported by the server, so the server is rejecting the request.

416.description: The range specified by the Range header field in the request cannot be fulfilled.

417.description: This response code means the expectation indicated by the Expect request header field cannot be met by the server.

418.description: The server refuses the attempt to brew coffee with a teapot.

421.description: The request was directed at a server that is not able to produce a response.

422.description: The request was well-formed but was unable to be followed due to semantic errors.

423.description: The resource that is being accessed is locked.

424.description: The request failed due to failure of a previous request.

425.description: Indicates that the server is unwilling to risk processing a request that might be replayed.

426.description: The server refuses to perform the request using the current protocol but might be willing to do so after the client upgrades to a different protocol.

428.description: The origin server requires the request to be conditional.

429.description: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time.

431.description: The server is unwilling to process the request because its header fields are too large.

451.description: The user agent requested a resource that cannot legally be provided, such as a web page censored by a government.

500.description: The server has encountered a situation it does not know how to handle.

501.description: The request method is not supported by the server and cannot be handled.

502.description: This error response means that the server, while working as a gateway to get a response needed to handle the request, got an invalid response.

503.description: The server is not ready to handle the request. Common causes are a server that is down for maintenance or that is overloaded.

504.description: This error response is given when the server is acting as a gateway and cannot get a response in time.

505.description: The HTTP version used in the request is not supported by the server.

506.description: The server has an internal configuration error.

507.description: The method could not be performed on the resource because the server is unable to store the representation needed to successfully complete the request.

508.description: The server detected an infinite loop while processing the request.

510.description: Further extensions to the request are required for the server to fulfill it.

511.description: Indicates that the client needs to authenticate to gain network access.
